question.text: Energyrequired to move a body of mass m from an orbit of radius $2 R \operatorname{to} 3 R$ is

solution.text:
Gravitational potential energy of mass $m$ in an orbit of radius $R$
$u=-\frac{G M m}{R}$
Energy required = potential energy at $3 \mathrm{R}-$ potential energy
$a 2 R$
$=\frac{-G M m}{3 R}-\left(\frac{-G M m}{2 R}\right)$
$=\frac{-G M m}{3 R}+\frac{G M m}{2 R}$
$=\frac{-2 G M m+3 G M m}{6 R}=\frac{G M m}{6 R}$

question.text: The kinetic energy needed to project a body of mass $m$ from the earth surface (radius $R$ ) to infinity is

solution.text:
$K . E=\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{2}$
Here $v_{e}=$ escape velocity is independent of mass of the body Escape velocity, $v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}$ Substituting value of $v_{e}$ in above cquation we get $K . E=\frac{1}{2} m \times 2 g R=m g R$

question.text: If suddenly the gravitational force of attraction between Earth and a satellite revolving around it becomes zero. then the satellite will

options.text: continue to move in its orbit with same velocity
move tangentially to the original orbit in the same velocity

solution.text: Due to incrtia of motion it will move tangentially to the original orbit with the same velocity.

question.text: The escape velocity of a body depends upon mass as

solution.text:
Escape velocity, $v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}$ $\Rightarrow v_{e} \propto m^{0}$
Where $M, R$ are the mass and radius of the planet respectively. Clearly, escape velocity is independent of mass of the body

question.text: Two spherical bodies of mass $M$ and $5 M \&$ radii $R \& 2 R$ respectively are released in free space with initial separation between their centres equal to $12 \mathrm{R}$. If they attract each other due to gravitational force only, then the distance covered by the smaller body just before collision is

solution.text:
We know that Force $=$ mass $\times$ acceleration.
The gravitational force acting on both the masses is the same. $F_{1}=F_{2}$ $m a_{1}=m a_{2}$ $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{9 M}{95 M}=\frac{5 M}{M}=5$ $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{9 M}{95 M}=\frac{1}{5}$ Let $t$ he the time taken for the two masses to collide and $x_{5 M}, \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{M}}$ be the distance travelled by the mass $5 M$ and $M$ respectively. For mass $5 M$, $u=0$ $S=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}$ $\therefore x_{5 M}=\frac{1}{2} a_{5 M} t^{2}$ ...(ii) For mass $M$ $u=0, s=x_{M}, t=t, a=a_{M}$ $\therefore s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}$ $\Rightarrow x_{M}=\frac{1}{2} a_{M} t^{2}$ ...(iii) Dividing (ii) by(iii) $\frac{x_{5 M}}{x_{M}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} a_{5 M} t^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} a_{M} t^{2}}=\frac{a_{5 M}}{a_{M}}=\frac{1}{5} \quad[$ From $(\mathrm{i})$ $\therefore 5 x_{5 M}=x_{M}$ ...(iv) From the figure it is clear that $x_{5 M}+x_{M}=9 R$ $\ldots .(\mathrm{v})$ Where $O$ is the point where the two spheres collide. From (iv) and (v) $\frac{x_{M}}{5}+x_{M}=9 R$ ...(v) $\therefore \quad 6 x_{M}=45 R$ $\therefore \quad x_{M}=\frac{45}{6} R=7.5 R$

question.text: The escape velocity for a body projected vertically upwards from the surface of carth is $11 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$. If the body is projccted at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the vertical, the escape velocity will be

solution.text:
$v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}$
Clearly escape velocity does not depend on the angle at which the body is projected.

question.text: If ' $g$ ' is the acceleration due to gravity on the earth's surface, the gain in the potential energy of an object of mass ' $\mathrm{m}$ " raised from the surfice of the earth to a height equal to the radius ' $R$ of the earth is

solution.text:
On earth's surface potential energy,
$U=\frac{G m M}{R}$
At a height $R$ from the earth's surface, $P . E .$ of system $=$
$-\frac{G m M}{2 R}$
$\therefore \Delta U=\frac{-G m M}{2 R}+\frac{G m M}{R}$
$\Rightarrow \Delta U=\frac{G m M}{2 R}$
Now $\frac{G M}{R^{2}}=g ; \therefore \frac{G M}{R}=g R \quad \therefore \Delta U=\frac{1}{2} m g R$

question.text: Suppose the gravitational force varies inversely as the nth power of distance. Then the time period of a planet in circular orbit of radius ' $R^{\prime}$ around the sun will be proportional to

solution.text:
Gravitational force, $F=K R^{-n}$ This force provides the centripetal force $M R \omega^{2}$ to the planet at height $h$ above earth's surface. $\therefore \quad F=K R^{-n}=M R \omega^{2}$
$\Rightarrow \quad \omega^{2}=K R^{-(n+1)}$
$\Rightarrow \omega=K R^{\frac{-(n+1)}{2}}$
$\frac{2 \pi}{T} \propto R^{\frac{-(n+1)}{2}}$
$\therefore T \propto R^{\frac{+(n+1)}{2}}$

question.text: The time period of an earth satellite in circular orbit is independent of

options.text: both the mass and radius of the orbit
neither the mass of the satellite nor the radius of its orbit.

solution.text:
Time period of satellite is given by $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{(R+h)^{3}}{G M}}$
Where $R+h=$ radius of orbit of satellite $M=$ mass of earth Time period is independent of mass of satellite.

question.text: A satellite of mass $m$ revolves around the earth of radius $R$ at a height $x$ from its surface. If $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth, the orbital speed of the satellite is

solution.text:
Gravitational force provides the necessary centripetal force $\therefore$ Centripetal force on a satellite = Gravitational force
$\therefore \quad \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=\frac{G m M}{(R+x)^{2}}$ also $g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$
$\therefore \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=m\left(\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\right) \frac{R^{2}}{(R+x)^{2}} \frac{n !}{r !(n-r) !}$
$\therefore \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=m g \frac{R^{2}}{(R+x)^{2}}$
$\therefore v^{2}=\frac{g R^{2}}{R+x} \Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{g R^{2}}{R+x}\right)^{1 / 2}$

question.text: The change in the value of ${ }^{6} g^{3}$ at a height ${ }^{\circ} h^{3}$ above the surface of the earth is the same as at a depth ' $d$ ' below the surface of earth. When both $d^{\prime \prime}$ and ${ }^{\prime} h^{\prime}$ are much smaller than the radius of earth, then which one of the following is correct?

solution.text:
Value of $g$ with altitude is, $g_{h}=g\left[1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right]$
Value of $g$ at depth d below earth's surface, $g_{d}=g\left[1-\frac{d}{R}\right]$
Equating $g_{h}$ and $g_{d}$, we get $d=2 h$

question.text: Average density of the earth

options.text: is a complex function of g

solution.text:
Value of $g$ on earth's surface,
$g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}=\frac{G \rho \times V}{R^{2}}$
$\Rightarrow g=\frac{G \times \rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{R^{2}}$
$g=\frac{4}{3} \rho \pi G . R$ where $\rho \rightarrow$ average density
$\rho=\left(\frac{3 g}{4 \pi G R}\right)$
$\Rightarrow \rho$ is directly proportional to $g$

question.text:
A particle of mass $10 \mathrm{~g}$ is kept on the surface of a uniform sphere of mass $100 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $10 \mathrm{~cm}$. Find the work to be done against the gravitational force between them to take the particle far away from the sphere
(you may take $\left.G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\right)$

solution.text:
Initial P.E. $U_{i}=-\frac{G M m}{R}$ When the particle is far away from the sphere, the P.E. of the system is zero. $\therefore \quad U_{f}=0$
$W=\Delta U=U_{f}-U_{i}=0-\left[\frac{-G M m}{R}\right]$
$W=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 100}{0.1} \times \frac{10}{1000} \quad=6.67 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~J}$

question.text:
This question contains Statement- $I$ and Statement- 2 . Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

Statement-1 : For a mass $M$ kept at the centre of a cube of side ' $a^{\prime}$, the flux of gravitational field passing through its sides $4 \pi G M$, and

Statenent-2: If the direction of a field due to a point source is radial and its dependence on the distance ' $r^{\prime}$ from the
source is given as $\frac{1}{r^{2}},$ its flux through a closed surface depends only on the strength of the source enclosed by the surface and not on the size or shape of the sur face.

options.text: Statement -1 is false, Statement- 2 is true
Statement -1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement -2 is a correct explanation for Statement- 1
Statement -1 is true, Statement- 2 is true, Statement 2 is not a correct explanation for Statement-1
Statement -1 is true, Statement -2 is false

solution.text:
Gravitational field, $E=-\frac{G M}{r^{2}}$
Flux, $\phi=\int \overrightarrow{E_{g}} \cdot \vec{d} S=\mid E \cdot 4 \pi r^{2} \models-4 \pi G M$
where, $M=$ mass enclosed in the closed surface This relationship is valid when $\left|\vec{E}_{g}\right| \mu \frac{1}{r^{2}}$

question.text: A planet in a distant solar system is 10 times more massive than the earth and its radius is 10 times smaller Given that the cscape velocity from the carth is $11 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, the cscape velocity from the surface of the planet would be

The height at which the acceleration due to gravity
becomes $\frac{g}{9}$ (where $g=$ the acceleration due to gravity on
the surface of the earth) in terms of $R$, the radius of the earth, is

solution.text:
On earth's surface $g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$
At height above earth's surface
$g_{h}=\frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}}$
$\therefore \frac{g_{n}}{g}=\frac{R^{2}}{(R+h)^{2}}$
$\Rightarrow \frac{g / 9}{g}=\left[\frac{R}{R+h}\right]^{2}$
$\Rightarrow \frac{R}{R+h}=\frac{1}{3}$
$\therefore \quad h=2 R$

question.text: Two particles of equal mass ' $m$ ' go around a circle of radius $R$ under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction. The speed of each particle with respect to their centre of mass is

solution.text: As two masses revolve about the common centre of $\operatorname{mass} O$ $\therefore \quad$ Mutual gravitational attraction $=$ centripetal force $\frac{G m^{2}}{(2 R)^{2}}=m \omega^{2} R$ $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}=\omega^{2}$ $\Rightarrow \quad \omega=\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}}$ If the velocity of the two particles with respect to the centre of gravity is $\mathrm{v}$ then $\begin{array}{l} v=\omega R \\ v=\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}} \times R=\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R}} \end{array}$

question.text: Two bodies of masses $m$ and $4 \mathrm{~m}$ are placed at a distancer. The gravitational potential at a point on the line joining them where the gravitational field is zero is:

solution.text:
Let $P$ be the point where gravitational field is zero. $\therefore \frac{G m}{x^{2}}=\frac{4 G m}{(r-x)^{2}}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x}=\frac{2}{r-x} \Rightarrow r-x=2 x \quad \Rightarrow x=\frac{r}{3}$
Gravitational potential at $P$ $V=-\frac{G m}{\frac{r}{3}}-\frac{4 G m}{\frac{2 r}{3}}=-\frac{9 G m}{r}$

question.text: The mass of a spaceship is $1000 \mathrm{~kg}$. It is to be launched from the earth's surface out into free space. The value of $g$ and $R$ (radius of earth) are $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ and $6400 \mathrm{~km}$ respectively. The required energy for this work will be

solution.text:
The work done to launch the spaceship
$W=-\int_{R}^{\infty} \vec{F} \cdot \overrightarrow{d r}=-\int_{R}^{\infty} \frac{G M m}{r^{2}} d r$
$W=+\frac{G M m}{R}$
(i) The force of attraction of the earth on the spaceship, when it was on the earth's surface
$F=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}}$
$\Rightarrow m g=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}} \Rightarrow g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$
Substituting the value of $g$ in (i) we get $W=\frac{g R^{2} m}{R}$
$\Rightarrow \quad W=m g R$
$\Rightarrow W=1000 \times 10 \times 6400 \times 10^{3}$
$=6.4 \times 10^{10}$ Joule

question.text: The variation of acceleration due to gravity g with distance d from centre of the earth is best represented by $(\mathrm{R}=$ Earth's radius):
Assuming the earth to be a sphere of uniform density, the acceleration due to gravity inside the earth at a distance of $r$ from the centre is proportional to

solution.text: Acceleration due to gravity at depth d from the surface of the earth or at a distance $r$ from the centre $^{\circ} O$ ' of the earth $g^{\prime}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G r$ Hence $g^{\prime} \propto r$

question.text: A point particle is held on the axis of a ring of mass $m$ and radius $r$ at a distance $r$ from its centre $C$. When released, it reaches $C$ under the gravitational attraction of the ring. Its speed at $C$ will be

solution.text:
Let ' $M$ be the mass of the particle Now, $E_{\text {initial }}=E_{\text {final }}$
i.e. $\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\sqrt{2} r}+0=\frac{\mathrm{GM} m}{r}+\frac{1}{2} M \mathrm{~V}^{2}$
or, $\frac{1}{2} M V^{2}=\frac{G M m}{r}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]$
$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} V^{2}=\frac{G m}{r}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]$
or, $V=\sqrt{\frac{2 G m}{r}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}$

question.text: The time period of a satellite of earth is 5 hours. If the separation between the earth and the satellite is increased to 4 times the previous value, the new time period will become

solution.text:
According to Kepler's law of periods $T^{2 \propto} R^{3}$ $\therefore\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)^{3}$
$\Rightarrow T_{2}=T_{1}\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)^{3 / 2}=5 \times\left[\frac{4 R}{R}\right]^{3 / 2}$
$=5 \times 2^{3}=40$ hours

question.text: What is the minimum energy required to launch a satellite of mass $\mathrm{m}$ from the surface of a planet of mass $\mathrm{M}$ and radius $R$ in a circular orbit at an altitude of $2 \mathrm{R}$ ?

solution.text:
As we know, Gravitational potential energy $=\frac{-G M m}{r}$ and orbital velocity, $v_{0}=\sqrt{\mathrm{GM} / \mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h}}$
$\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}} &=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{3 \mathrm{R}}-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}} \\
&=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}}\left(\frac{1}{2}-1\right)=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{6 \mathrm{R}}
\end{aligned}$
$\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}}+\mathrm{K}$
$E_{i}=E_{f}$
Therefore minimum required energy, $\mathrm{K}=\frac{5 \mathrm{GMm}}{6 \mathrm{R}}$

question.text: The gravitational field, due to the 'left over part' of a uniform sphere (from which a part as shown, has been 'removed out'), at a very far off point, P, located as shown, would be (nearly):

solution.text:
Let mass of smaller sphere(which has to beremoved) is m
Radius $=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}$ (from figure)
$\frac{\mathrm{M}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{R}^{3}}=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}\right)^{3}}$
$\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}=\frac{\mathrm{M}}{8}$
Mass of the left over part of the sphere
$M^{\prime}=M-\frac{M}{8}=\frac{7}{8} M$
Therefore gravitational field due to the left over part of the sphere
$=\frac{\mathrm{GM}^{+}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}=\frac{7}{8} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}$

question.text:
The change in the value of acceleration of earth towards sun, when the moon comes from the position of solar eclipse to the position on the other side of earth in line with sun is:
(mass of the moon $=7.36 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$, radius of the moon's orbit $\left.=3.8 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m}\right)$.

solution.text: $6.73 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$

question.text: Four particles, each of mass $\mathrm{M}$ and equidistant from each other, move along a circle of radius $\mathrm{R}$ under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction. The speed of each particle is:

solution.text:
$2 F \cos 45^{\circ}+F^{\prime}=\frac{M v^{2}}{R}$ (From figure) Where $F=\frac{G M^{2}}{(\sqrt{2} R)^{2}}$ and $F^{\prime}=\frac{G M^{2}}{4 R^{2}}$
$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{2 \times G M^{2}}{\sqrt{2}(R \sqrt{2})^{2}}+\frac{G M^{2}}{4 R^{2}}=\frac{M v^{2}}{R}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{G M^{2}}{R}\left[\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]=M v^{2}$ $\therefore v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}+4}{4 \sqrt{2}}\right)}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}(1+2 \sqrt{2})}$

question.text: India's Mangalyan was sent to the Mars by launching it into a transfer orbit EOM around the sun. It leaves the earth at $\mathrm{E}$ and meets Mars at $\mathrm{M}$. If the semi-major axis of Earth's orbit is $a_{e}=1.5 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m},$ that of Mars orbit $a_{\mathrm{m}}=$ $2.28 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m}$, taken Kepler's laws give the estimate of time for Mangalyan to reach Mars from Earth to be close to:

solution.text: 320 days

question.text: From a sphere of mass M and radius $R$, a smaller sphere of radius $\frac{R}{2}$ is carved out such that the cavity made in the original sphere is between its centre and the periphery (See figure). For the configuration in the figure where the distance between the centre of the original sphere and the removed sphere is $3 \mathrm{R}$, the gravitational force between the two sphere is:

solution.text:
Volume of removed sphere
$V_{\mathrm{remo}}=\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)$
Volume of the sphere (remaining) $V_{\text {remain }}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}-\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{7}{8}\right)$
Therefore mass of sphere carved and remaining sphere are at respectively $\frac{1}{8} \mathrm{M}$ and $\frac{7}{8} \mathrm{M}$ Therefore, gravitational force between these two sphere, $F=\frac{G M m}{r^{2}}=\frac{G \frac{7 M}{8} \times \frac{1}{8} M}{(3 R)^{2}}=\frac{7}{64 \times 9} \frac{G M^{2}}{R^{2}}$
$\simeq \frac{41}{3600} \frac{\mathrm{GM}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$

question.text: Two hypothetical planets of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are at rest when they are infinite distance apart. Because of the gravitational force they move towards each other along the line joining their centres. What is their speed when their separation is 'd'? (Speed of $m_{1}$ is $v_{1}$ and that of $m_{2}$ is $\left.v_{2}\right)$

solution.text:
We choose reference point, infinity, where total energy of the system is zero. So, initial energy of the system $=0$
Final energy $=\frac{1}{2} m_{1} v_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2} v_{2}^{2}-\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{d}$
From conservation of energy, Initial energy $=$ Final energy
$\therefore 0=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{Gm}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}}$
or $\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{Gm}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}} \ldots(1)$
By conservation of linear momentum
$\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{2}=0$ or $\frac{\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{v}_{2}}=-\frac{\mathrm{m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}} \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_{2}=-\frac{\mathrm{m}_{1}}{\mathrm{~m}_{2}} \mathrm{v}_{1}$
Putting value of $v_{2}$ in equation (1), we get $m_{1} v_{1}^{2}+m_{2}\left(-\frac{m_{1} v_{1}}{m_{2}}\right)^{2}=\frac{2 G m_{1} m_{2}}{d}$
$\frac{m_{1} m_{2} v_{1}^{2}+m_{1}^{2} v_{1}^{2}}{m_{2}}=\frac{2 G m_{1} m_{2}}{d}$
$v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G m_{2}^{2}}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}=m_{2} \sqrt{\frac{2 G}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}$
Similarly $v_{2}=-m_{1} \sqrt{\frac{2 G}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}$

question.text:
The gravitational field in a region is given by
$\overrightarrow{\mathrm{g}}=5 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+12 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \hat{\mathrm{j}}$. The change in the gravitational
potential energy of a particle of mass $1 \mathrm{~kg}$ when it is taken from the origin to a point $(7 \mathrm{~m},-3 \mathrm{~m})$ is:

solution.text:
Gravitational field, $I=(5 \hat{i}+12 \hat{j}) \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{kg}$
$\mathrm{I}=-\frac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{dr}}$
$\mathrm{v}=-\left[\int_{0}^{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{dx}+\int_{0}^{\mathrm{y}} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{y}} \mathrm{dy}\right]$
$=-\left[\mathbf{I}_{\left.\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{X}+\mathbf{I}_{\mathbf{y}} \cdot \mathbf{y}\right]}\right.$
$=-[5(7-0)+12(-3-0)]$
$=-[35+(-36)]=1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}$
i.e., change in gravitational potential $1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}$. Hence change in gravitational potential energy $1 \mathrm{~J}$

question.text: From a solid sphere of mass $\mathrm{M}$ and radius $\mathrm{R},$ a spherical portion of radius $\mathrm{R} / 2$ is removed, as shown in the figure. Taking gravitational potential $\mathrm{V}=0$ at $\mathrm{r}=\infty,$ the potential at the centre of the cavity thus formed is : $(G=$ gravitational constant $)$

solution.text:
Due to complete solid sphere, potential at point $P$ $\mathrm{V}_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{2 \mathrm{R}^{3}}\left[3 \mathrm{R}^{2}-\left(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}\right)^{2}\right]$ $=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{2 \mathrm{R}^{3}}\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{R}^{2}}{4}\right)=-11 \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}$
Due to cavity part potential at point $P$ $\mathrm{V}_{\text {cavity }}=-\frac{3}{2} \frac{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{8}}{\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}}=-\frac{3 \mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}$ So potential at the centre of cavity $=\mathrm{V}_{\text {sphere }}-\mathrm{V}_{\text {cavity }}$ $=-\frac{11 \mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}-\left(-\frac{3}{8} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}\right)=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}$

question.text:
A very long (length
L) cylindrical galaxy is made of uniformly distributed mass and has radius $R(R< < L)$. A star outside the galaxy is orbiting the galaxy in a plane perpendicular to the galaxy and passing through its centre. If the time period of star is $\mathrm{T}$ and its distance from the galaxy's axis is $r$, then :

solution.text:
$F=\frac{2 G M}{L r} m$ or, $\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{2 G M}{L r} m$
$m r\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^{2}=\frac{2 G M m}{L r}\left[\because v=r \omega \text { and } \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right]$
$\Rightarrow \quad T \propto r$

question.text: Which of the following most closely depicts the correct variation of the gravitational potential $\mathrm{V}(\mathrm{r})$ due to a large planet of radius $\mathrm{R}$ and uniform mass density ? (figures are not drawn to scale)

solution.text:
As, $V=-\frac{G M}{2 R^{3}}\left(3 R^{2}-r^{2}\right)$
Graph (c) most closely depicts the correct variation of $v(r)$

question.text: A satellite is revolving in a circular orbit at a height 'h' from the earth's surface (radius of earth $\mathrm{R} ; \mathrm{h}< < \mathrm{R}$ ). The minimum increase in its orbital velocityrequired, so that the satellite could escape from the earth's gravitational field, is close to : (Neglect the cffect of atmosphere.)

solution.text:
For $\mathrm{h}< < \mathrm{R},$ the orbital velocity is $\sqrt{\mathrm{gR}}$
Escape velocity $=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gR}}$
$\therefore$ The minimum increase in its orbital velocity $=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gR}}-\sqrt{\mathrm{gR}}=\sqrt{\mathrm{gR}}(\sqrt{2}-1)$

question.text: Figure shows elliptical path abcd of a planet around the sun S such that the area of triangle csa is $\frac{1}{4}$ the area of the ellipse. (See figure) With db as the semimajor axis, and ca as the semiminor axis. If $t$, is the time taken for planet to go over path abc and $t_{2}$ for path taken over cda then:

solution.text:
Let area of ellipse abcd $=x$ Area of $\operatorname{SabcS}=\frac{x}{2}+\frac{x}{4}($ i.e., ar of abca $+$ SacS $)$ (Area of halfellipse + Area of triangle) $=\frac{3 x}{4}$
Area of $\operatorname{SadcS}=x-\frac{3 x}{4}=\frac{x}{4}$ $\frac{\text { Area of } \operatorname{SabcS}}{\text { Area of } \operatorname{SadcS}}=\frac{3 x / 4}{x / 4}=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}$ $\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=3$ or, $t_{1}=3 t_{2}$

question.text: An astronaut of mass $m$ is working on a satellite orbiting the earth at a distance h from the earth's surface. The radius of the earth is $R$, while its mass is $M$. The gravitational pull $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{G}}$ on the astronaut is:

solution.text: According to universal law of Gravitation, Gravitational force $\mathrm{F}=\frac{\text { GMm }}{(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h})^{2}}$

question.text: The variation of acceleration due to gravity g with distance d from centre of the earth is best represented by $(\mathrm{R}=$ Earth's radius):

If the Earth has no rotational motion, the weight of a person on the equator is W. Determine the speed with which the earth would have to rotate about its axis so that the person
at the equator will weight $\frac{3}{4} \mathrm{~W}$. Radius of the Earth is $6400 \mathrm{~km}$ and $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$

solution.text:
We know, $g^{\prime \prime}=g-\omega^{2} R \cos ^{2} \theta$

question.text:
Take the mean distance of the moon and the sun from the earth to be $0.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and $150 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ respectively. Their masses are $8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$ and $2 \times 10^{30} \mathrm{~kg}$ respectively The radius of the earth is $6400 \mathrm{~km}$. Let $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}$ be the difference in the forces exerted by the moon at the nearest and farthest points on the earth and $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}$ be the difference in the force exerted by the sun at the nearest and farthest points on
the earth. Then, the number closest to $\frac{\Delta F_{1}}{\Delta F_{2}}$ is:

solution.text:
As we know, Gravitational force of attraction,
$\mathrm{F}=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$
$\mathrm{F}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{2}}$ and $\mathrm{F}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{2}}$
$\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}=\frac{2 \mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}$ and $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}$
$\frac{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{m} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}} \frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}}{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}\right)\left(\frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}}\right)$
Using $\Delta r_{1}=\Delta r_{2}=2 R_{\text {earth }} ; m=8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$
$\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}=2 \times 10^{30} \mathrm{~kg}$
$r_{1}=0.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and $\mathrm{r}_{2}=150 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$
$\frac{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}}=\left(\frac{8 \times 10^{22}}{2 \times 10^{30}}\right)\left(\frac{150 \times 10^{6}}{0.4 \times 10^{6}}\right)^{3} \times 1 \cong 2$

question.text:
A body of mass $m$ is moving in a circular orbit of radius $R$ about a planet of mass $M$. At some instant, it splits into two equal masses. The first mass moves in a circular orbit
of radius $\frac{R}{2},$ and the other mass, in a circular orbit of
radius $\frac{3 R}{2} .$ The difference between the final and initial
total energies is:

solution.text:
Initial gravitational potential energy, $E_{i}=-\frac{G M m}{2 R}$ Final gravitational potential energy,
$\begin{array}{l}
E_{f}=-\frac{G M m / 2}{2\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)}-\frac{G M m / 2}{2\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)}=-\frac{G M m}{2 R}-\frac{G M m}{6 R} \\
=-\frac{4 G M m}{6 R}=\frac{2 G M m}{3 R}
\end{array}$
$\therefore$ Difference between initial and final energy,
$E_{f}-E_{i}=\frac{G M m}{R}\left(-\frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{2}\right)=-\frac{G M m}{6 R}$

question.text: Suppose that the angular velocity of rotation of earth is increased. Then, as a consequence.

options.text: There will be no change in weight anywhere on the earth
Weight of the object, everywhere on the earth, wild decrease
Weight of the object, everywhere on the earth, will incrense
Except at poles, weight of the object on the earth will decrease

solution.text:
With rotation of earth or latitude, acceleration due to gravity vary as $g^{\prime}=g-\omega^{2} R \cos ^{2} \phi$
Where ф is latitude, there will be no change in gravity at poles as $\phi=90^{\circ}$ At all other points as $\omega$ increases $\mathrm{g}^{\prime}$ will decreases hence, weight, $W=m g$ decreases.

question.text: If the angular momentum of a planet of mass $\mathrm{m}$, moving around the Sun in a circular orbit is $L,$ about the center of the Sun, its areal velocity is:

solution.text:
Areal velocity; $\frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}$
$\mathrm{d} \mathrm{A}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{r}^{2} \mathrm{~d} \theta$
$\Rightarrow \frac{d A}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} r^{2} \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} r^{2} \omega$
Also, $L=m v r=m r^{2} \omega$
$\therefore \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{L}}{\mathrm{m}}$

question.text: The energy required to take a satellite to a height 'h' above Earth surface (radius of Eareth $=6.4 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~km}$ ) is $\mathrm{E}_{1}$ and kinetic energy required for the satellite to be in a circular orbit at this height is $\mathrm{E}_{2}$. The value of $\mathrm{h}$ for which $\mathrm{E}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{E}_{3}$ are equal, is:

solution.text:
K.E. of satellite is zero at earth surface and at height h from energy conservation $\mathrm{U}_{\text {surface }}+\mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{h}}$
$\begin{aligned} &-\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}+\mathrm{E}_{1}=-\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{(\mathrm{Re}+\mathrm{h})} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}}\right) \end{aligned} \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)} \times \frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}$
Gravitational attraction
$\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{G}}=\mathrm{ma}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)^{2}}$
$\mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)}$
$\mathrm{E}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{2\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)}$
$\mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{E}_{2}$
Clearly, $\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}{2}=3200 \mathrm{~km}$

question.text: A satellite is moving with a constant speed $v$ in circular orbit around the earth. An object of mass ' $\mathrm{m}^{\prime}$ is ejected from the satellite such that it just escapes from the gravitational pull of the earth. At the time of ejection, the kinetic energy of the object is:

solution.text:
At height $r$ from center of earth, orbital velocity
$v=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{r}}$
By principle of energy conservation $\mathrm{KE}$ of $^{2} \mathrm{~m}^{\prime}+\left(-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}\right)=0+0$
$(\because$ At infinity, $P E=K E=0)$ $\alpha \mathrm{KE} \circ \mathrm{f}^{6} \mathrm{~m}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}=\left(\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~m}=\mathrm{mv}^{2}$

question.text:
Two stars of masses $3 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{~kg}$ each, and at distance of mass O. A meteorite passes through O moving perpen-dicular to the star's rotation plane. In order to escape from the gravitational field of this double star, the minimum speed that meteorite should have at $\mathrm{O}$ is:
(Take Gravitational constant $\mathrm{G}=66 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}$ )

solution.text:
Let $M$ is mass of star $m$ is mass of meteroite
By energy convervation between 0 and $\infty$,
$-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}+\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~V}_{\infty}^{2}=0+0$
$\therefore \mathrm{v}^{-} \sqrt{\frac{4 \mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \times 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 3 \times 10^{31}}{10^{11}}}$
$=2.8 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$

question.text: A satellite is revolving in a circular orbit at a height h from the carth surface, such that $\mathrm{h}< < \mathrm{R}$ where $\mathrm{R}$ is the radius of the earth. Assuming that the effect of earth"s atmosphere can be neglected the minimum increase in the speed required so that the satellite could escape from the gravitational field of earth is

solution.text:
For a satellite orbiting close to the earth, orbital velocity is given by
$v_{0}=\sqrt{g(R+h)}=\sqrt{g R}$
Escape velocity $\left(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{e}}\right)$ is
$v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g(R+h)}=\sqrt{2 g R} \quad[\because h  < c R$
$\Delta v=v_{e}-v_{0}=(\sqrt{2}-1) \sqrt{g R}$

question.text: A straight rod of length $\mathrm{L}$ extends from $x=a$ to $x=\mathrm{L}+\mathrm{a}$. The gravitational force it exerts on point mass ' $\mathrm{m}$ ' at $x=0$, if the mass per unit length of the rod is $\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} x^{2},$ is given by:

solution.text:
Given $\lambda=\left(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{Bx}^{2}\right)$, Taking small element dm of length dx at a distance from $x=0$
$\mathrm{dF}=\frac{\mathrm{Gmdm}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}$
$\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\int_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{L}} \frac{\mathrm{Gm}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}\left(\mathrm{~A}+\mathrm{Bx}^{2}\right) \mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}$
$=\mathrm{Gm}\left[-\frac{\mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{x}}+\mathrm{Bx}\right]_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{L}}$
$=\mathrm{Gm}\left[\mathrm{A}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{a}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{L}}\right)+\mathrm{BL}\right]$

question.text:
The ratio of the weights of a body on the Earth's surface to that on the surface of a planet is 9: 4 . The mass of the
planet is $\frac{1}{9}$ th of that of the Earth. If ' $R$ ' is the radius of the Earth, what is the radius of the planet? (Take the planets to have the same mass density).

solution.text:
$\frac{W_{e}}{W_{p}}=\frac{m g_{e}}{m g_{p}}=\frac{9}{4}$ or $\frac{g_{e}}{g_{p}}=\frac{9}{4}$
or $\frac{G M / R^{2}}{G(M / 9) / R_{p}^{2}}=\frac{9}{4}$
$\therefore \quad R_{p}=\frac{R}{2}$

question.text: A satellite of mass $\mathrm{M}$ is in a circular orbit of radius $\mathrm{R}$ about the centre of the earth. A meteorite of the same mass, falling towards the earth collides with the satellite completely in clastically. The specds of the satellite and the metcorite are the same, Just before the collision. The subsequent motion of the combined body will be

options.text: such that it escape to infinity
in the same circular orbit of radius $\mathbb{R}$
in a circular orbit of a different radius

solution.text: $\mathrm{mvi}+\mathrm{mvj}=2 \mathrm{mv}$ $\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2} \hat{\mathrm{j}}$ $\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\sqrt{2}}$ $=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \times \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}}$

question.text: Two satellites, Aand B, have masses $m$ and 2 m respectively. A is in a circular orbit of radius $\mathrm{R}$, and $\mathrm{B}$ is in a circular orbit of radius $2 \mathrm{R}$ around the earth. The ratio of their kinetic energies, $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{A}} / \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}$, is :

solution.text:
Orbital, velocity, $\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}$
Kinetic energy of satellite A $T_{A}=\frac{1}{2} m_{A} V_{A}^{2}$
Kinetic energy of satellite B. $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}$
$\Rightarrow \frac{T_{A}}{T_{B}}=\frac{m \times \frac{G M}{R}}{2 m \times \frac{G M}{2 R}}=1$

question.text: Four identical particles of mass M are located at the corners of a square of side ' $a$ '. What should be their speed if each of them revolves under the influence of others? gravitational field in a circular orbit circumscribing the square?

solution.text:
$A C=a \sqrt{2} \quad \because r=\frac{A C}{2}=\frac{a \sqrt{2}}{2}=\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}$ Resultant force on the body $B=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \hat{i}+\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \hat{j}+\frac{G M^{2}}{(a \sqrt{2})^{2}}\left(\cos 45^{\circ} \hat{i}+\sin 45^{\circ} \hat{j}\right)$ $\Rightarrow|F|=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}}(\sqrt{2})+\frac{G M^{2}}{2 a^{2}}$
$\frac{M v^{2}}{r}=$ Resultant force towards centre $\therefore \frac{M v^{2}}{\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}}\left(\sqrt{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right)$ $\Rightarrow v^{2}=\frac{G M}{a}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)$ $\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{a}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)}=1.16 \sqrt{\frac{G M}{a}}$

question.text:
A test particle is moving in circular orbit in the gravitational
field produced by a mass density $r(r)=\frac{K}{r^{2}} .$ Identify the
correct relation between the radius $\mathrm{R}$ of the particle's orbit and its period T:

solution.text:
$F=\frac{G M m}{r}=\int a \frac{\rho(d V) m}{r^{2}}$
$\begin{array}{l}
=m G \int_{0}^{R} \frac{k}{r^{2}} \frac{4 \pi r^{2} d r}{r^{2}} \\
=-4 \pi k G m\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)_{0}^{R} \\
=-\frac{4 \pi k G m}{R}
\end{array}$
Using Newton's second law, we have
$\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{R}=\frac{4 \pi k G m}{R}$
or $v_{0}=\mathrm{C}$ (const.) Time period, $T=\frac{2 \pi R}{v_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi R}{C}$
or $=\frac{T}{R}=$ constant

question.text: A rocket has to be launched from earth in such a way that it never returns. If $E$ is the minimum energy delivered by the rocket launcher, what should be the minimum energy that the launcher should have if the same rocket is to be launched from the surface of the moon? Assume that the density of the earth and the moon are equal and that the earth's volume is 64 times the volume of the moon.

solution.text:
Escape velocity, $v_{c}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \rho V}{R}}$
$=\sqrt{\frac{2 G S \times 4 \pi R^{3}}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G R^{2}}$
For moon, $v_{c}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G R_{m}^{2}}$
Given, $\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}=64 \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R_{m}^{3}$ or $R_{m}=\frac{R}{4}$
$\therefore \quad v_{e}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G\left(\frac{R}{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{v_{c}}{4}$
$\frac{E}{E^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{\prime 2}}=\frac{v_{e}^{2}}{v_{c}^{\prime 2}}=\frac{v_{e}}{\left(\frac{v_{e}}{4}\right)}=16$
or $E^{\prime}=\frac{E}{16}$

question.text: A solid sphere of mass 'M' and radius 'a' is surrounded by a uniform concentric spherical shell of thickness $2 \mathrm{a}$ and mass $2 \mathrm{M}$. The gravitational field at distance ' $3 \mathrm{a}$ ' from the centre will be:

The value of acceleration due to gravity at Earth's surface is $9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$. The altitude above its surface at which the acceleration due to gravity decreases to $4.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$, is close to : (Radius of earth $=6.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$ )

solution.text:
Given Acceleration due to gravity at a height h from earth's surface is 
$\begin{array}{l}
g_{h}=g\left(1+\frac{h}{R_{e}}\right)^{-2} \Rightarrow 4.9=9.8\left(1+\frac{h}{R_{e}}\right)^{-2} \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\left(1-\frac{h}{R_{e}}\right) \quad[\text { as } h<< < R] \\
h=R_{e}(\sqrt{2}-1) \\
h=6400 \times 0.414 \mathrm{~km}=2.6 \times 10^{\circ} \mathrm{m}
\end{array}$

question.text: A spaceship orbits around a planet at a height of $20 \mathrm{~km}$ from its surface. Assuming that only gravitational field of the planet acts on the spaceship, what will be the number of complete rcvolutions made by the spaceship in 24 hours around the planct? [Given : Mass of Planct $=8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$, Radius of planet $=2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m},$ Gravitational constant $\left.\mathrm{G}=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\right]$

solution.text:
Time period of revolution of satellite,
$T=\frac{2 \pi r}{v}$
$v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r}}$
$\therefore T=2 \pi r \sqrt{\frac{r}{G M}}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{r^{3}}{G M}}$
Substituting the values, we get
$T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{(202)^{3} \times 10^{12}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 8 \times 10^{22}}} \sec$
$\mathrm{T}=7812.2 \mathrm{~s}$
$\mathrm{T} \simeq 2.17 \mathrm{hr} \Rightarrow 11$ revolutions

question.text:
A satellite of mass $m$ is launched vertically upwards with an initial spced $u$ from the surface of the carth. After it reaches height $R(R=$ radius of the earth), it
ejects a rocket of mass $\frac{m}{10}$ so that subsequently the
satcllite moves in a circular orbit. The kinctic energy of the rocket is ( $G$ is the gravitational constant; $M$ is the mass of the earth):

solution.text:
$(R,)^{M} \rightarrow \Rightarrow(R,)^{M} \longleftrightarrow \underset{m}{\odot} \rightarrow v$ $\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}+\frac{-G M m}{R}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{-G M m}{2 R}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m\left(v^{2}-u^{2}\right)=\frac{-G M m}{2 R}$ $\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=\sqrt{\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{u}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}}$ $v_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 R}} \quad \therefore v_{r a d}=\frac{m \times v}{\left(\frac{m}{10}\right)}=10 v$ Ejecting a rocket of mass $\frac{m}{10}$ $\therefore \frac{9 m}{10} \times \sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 R}}=\frac{m}{10} \times v_{\tau} \Rightarrow V_{\tau}^{2}=81 \frac{G M}{2 R}$ Kinetic energy of rocket, $\mathrm{KE}_{\text {rocket }}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{M}{10}\left(V_{T}^{2}+V_{r}^{2}\right)$ $=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{m}{10} \times\left(\left(u^{2}-\frac{G M}{R}\right) 100+81 \frac{G M}{R}\right)$ $=\frac{m}{20} \times 100\left(u^{2}-\frac{G M}{R}+\frac{81}{200} \frac{G M}{R}\right)$
$=5 m\left(u^{2}-\frac{119}{200} \frac{G M}{R}\right)$

question.text: A box weighs $196 \mathrm{~N}$ on a spring balance at the north pole. Its weight recorded on the same balance if it is shifled to the cquator is close to (Take $g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ at the north pole and the radius of the earth $=6400 \mathrm{~km}$ ):

solution.text:
Weight at pole, $w=m g=196 N$
$\Rightarrow \quad m=19.6 \mathrm{~kg}$
Weight at equator, $w^{\prime}=m g^{\prime}=m\left(g-\omega^{2} R\right)$
$\begin{array}{l}
=19.6\left[10-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{24 \times 3600}\right)^{2} \times 6400 \times 10^{3}\right] \mathrm{N} \\
\left(\because \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right) \\
=19.6[10-0.034]=195.33 \mathrm{~N}
\end{array}$

question.text: Consider two solid spheres of radii $R_{1}=1 m, R_{2}=2 m$ and masses $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$, respectively. The gravitational field due to sphere 1 and (2) are shown. The value of $\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}$ is:

solution.text:
Gravitation field at the surface
$E=\frac{G m}{r^{2}}$
$\therefore E_{1}=\frac{G m_{1}}{r_{1}^{2}}$ and $E_{2}=\frac{G m_{2}}{r_{2}^{2}}$
From the diagram given in question,
$\frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{2}{3}\left(r_{1}=1 \mathrm{~m}, R_{2}=2 m\right.$ given $)$
$\therefore \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\left(\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right) \Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}=\left(\frac{2}{1}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right)$
$\Rightarrow\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{6}$

question.text:
A body A of mass $m$ is moving in a circular or bit of radius
$\mathrm{R}$ about a planet. Another body $\mathrm{B}$ of mass $\frac{m}{2}$ collides with
A with a velocity which is half $\left(\frac{\vec{v}}{2}\right)$ the instantaneous
velocity $\vec{v}$ or $A$. The collision is completely inelastic. Then, the combined body:

options.text: continues to move in a circular orbit
Escapes from the Planet's Gravitational ficld
Falls vertically downwards towards the planet
starts moving in an elliptical orbit around the planet

solution.text:
From law of conservation of momentum, $\vec{p}_{i}=\vec{p}_{f}$
$m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=M V_{t}$
$\Rightarrow v_{f}=\frac{\left(m v+\frac{m v}{4}\right)}{\frac{3 m}{2}}=\frac{5 v}{6}$

question.text:
Planet A has mass $\mathrm{M}$ and radius $\mathrm{R}$. Planet $\mathrm{B}$ has half the mass and half the radius of Planet A. If the escape velocities from the Planets $A$ and $B$ are $v_{A}$ and $v_{1},$ respectively, then
$\frac{v_{\mathrm{A}}}{v_{\mathrm{B}}}=\frac{n}{4}$, The value of $n$ is

solution.text:
Escape velocity of the planet $A$ is $V_{A}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{A}}{R_{A}}}$
where $M_{A}$ and $R_{A}$ be the mass and radius of the plane $A$
According to given problem
$M_{B}=\frac{M_{A}}{2}, R_{B}=\frac{R_{A}}{2}$
$\therefore V_{B}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \frac{M_{A}}{2}}{\frac{R_{A}}{2}}} \therefore \frac{V_{A}}{V_{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{\frac{2 G M_{A}}{R_{A}}}{\frac{2 G M_{A} / 2}{R_{A} / 2}}}=\frac{n}{4}=1$
$\Rightarrow \quad n=4$

question.text: The mass density of a spherical galaxy varies as $\frac{K}{r}$ over a large distance ' $r^{\prime}$ from its centre. In that region, a small star is in a circular orbit of radius $R$. Then the period of revolution, $T$ depends on $R$ as

solution.text: According to question, mass density of a spherical galaxy varies as $\frac{k}{r}$ Mass, $M=\int \rho d V$ $\Rightarrow M=\int_{0}^{r=R_{0}} \frac{k}{r} 4 \pi r^{2} d r$ $\Rightarrow M=4 \pi k \int_{0}^{R_{0}} r d r$ or, $M=\frac{4 \pi k R_{0}^{2}}{2}=2 \pi k R^{2}$ $F_{G}=\frac{G M m}{R_{0}^{2}}=m \omega_{0}^{2} R\left(=F_{C}\right)$ $\Rightarrow \frac{G \frac{4 \pi k R^{2}}{2}}{R^{2}}=\omega_{0}^{2} R \Rightarrow \omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi K G}{R}} \quad\left(\because \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)$ $\therefore T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi \sqrt{R}}{\sqrt{2 \pi K G}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi R}{K G}} \Rightarrow T^{2}=\frac{2 \pi R}{K G}$ $\because 2 \pi, K$ and $G$ are constants $\therefore T^{2} \propto R$

question.text: The height ' $h$ ' at which the weight of a body will be the same as that at the same depth ' $\bar{h}$ ' from the surface of the earth is (Radius of the earth is $R$ and effect of the rotation of the earth is neglected):

solution.text:
The acceleration due to gravity at a height $h$ is given by
$g=\frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}
Here, $G=$ gravitation constant $M=$ mass of earth
The acceleration due to gravity at depth $h$ is
$g^{\prime}=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\left(1-\frac{h}{R}\right)$
Given, $g=g^{\prime}$
$\begin{array}{l}
\therefore \frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}}=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\left(1-\frac{h}{R}\right) \\
\therefore R^{3}=(R+h)^{2}(R-h)=\left(R^{2}+h^{2}+2 h R\right)(R-h) \\
\Rightarrow R^{3}=R^{3}+h^{2} R+2 h R^{2}-R^{2} h-h^{3}-2 h^{2} R \\
\Rightarrow h^{3}+h^{2}(2 R-R)-R^{2} h=0 \\
\Rightarrow h^{3}+h^{2} R-R^{2} h=0 \\
\Rightarrow h^{2}+h R-R^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow h=\frac{-R \pm \sqrt{R^{2}+4(1) R^{2}}}{2} \\
\quad=\frac{-R+\sqrt{5} R}{2}=\frac{(\sqrt{5}-1)}{2} R
\end{array}$

question.text:
A satellite is moving in a low nearly circular orbit around the earth. Its radius is roughly equal to that of the earth's radius $R_{e}$. By firing rockets attached to it, its speed is instantaneously increased in the direction of its motion so
that it become $\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}$ times larger. Due to this the farthest
distance from the centre of the carth that the satellite reaches is $R$. Value of $R$ is

solution.text: Orbital velocity, $V_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R_{e}}}$ From energy conversation, $-\frac{G M m}{R_{e}}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} V\right)^{2}=\frac{G M m}{R_{\max }}+\frac{1}{2} m V_{\min }^{2}$ From angular momentum conversation $\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} V R_{e}=V_{\min } R_{\max }$ Solving equation (1) and (2) we get, $R_{\max }=3 R_{e}$

question.text:
The mass density of a planet of radius $R$ varies with the
distance $r$ from its centre as $\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right)$. Then the gravitational field is maximum at

solution.text: Mass of small element of planet of radius $x$ and thickness $d x$ $d m=\rho \times 4 \pi x^{2} d x=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{x^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) \times 4 \pi x^{2} d x$ Mass of the planet $\begin{aligned} M &=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{r}\left(x^{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{R^{2}}\right) d x \\ \Rightarrow M &=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left|\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{2}}\right| \end{aligned}$ Gravitational field, $\begin{aligned} E &=\frac{G M}{r^{2}}=\frac{G}{r^{2}} \times 4 \pi \rho_{0}\left(\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{2}}\right) \\ \Rightarrow E &=4 \pi G \rho_{0}\left(\frac{r}{3}-\frac{r^{3}}{5 R^{2}}\right) \end{aligned}$ $E$ is maximum when $\frac{d E}{d r}=0$ $\begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \frac{d E}{d r}=4 \pi G \rho_{0}\left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{3 r^{2}}{5 R^{2}}\right)=0 \\ \Rightarrow r=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} R \end{array}$

question.text:
On the $x$ -axis and at a distance $x$ from the origin, the gravitational field due to a mass distribution is given by
$\frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}$ in the $x$ -direction. The magnitude of gravitational potential on the $x$ -axis at a distance $x$, taking its value to be zero at infinity, is :

solution.text:
Given : Gravitational field,
$E_{G}=\frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}, V_{\infty}=0$
$\int_{V_{\infty}}^{V_{X}} d V=-\int_{\infty}^{x} \vec{E}_{G} \cdot \vec{d}_{x}$
$\Rightarrow V_{x}-V_{\infty}=-\int_{\infty}^{x} \frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} d x$
$\therefore V_{x}=\frac{A}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}-0=\frac{A}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}$

question.text: A body is moving in a low circular orbit about a planet of mass $M$ and radius $R$. The radius of the orbit can be taken to be $R$ itself. Then the ratio of the speed of this body in the orbit to the escape velocity from the planet is :

solution.text:
Orbital speed of the body when it revolves very close to the surface of planet
$V_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}}$
Here, $G=$ gravitational constant Escape speed from the surface of planet
$V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}$
Dividing (i) by (ii), we have
$\frac{V_{0}}{V_{e}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

question.text:
The value of acceleration due to gravity is $g_{1}$ at a height
$h=\frac{R}{2}(R=$ radius of the earth) from the surface of the earth. It is again equal to $g_{1}$ and a depth $d$ below the surface of the earth. The ratio $\left(\frac{d}{R}\right)$ equals:

solution.text:
According to question, $g_{h}=g_{d}=g$.
$g_{h}=\frac{G M}{\left(R+\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}}$ and $g_{d}=\frac{G M(R-d)}{R^{3}}$ $\frac{G M}{\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{G M(R-d)}{R^{3}} \Rightarrow \frac{4}{9}=\frac{(R-d)}{R}$ $\Rightarrow 4 R=9 R-9 d \Rightarrow 5 R=9 d$ $\therefore \frac{d}{R}=\frac{5}{9}$

question.text: The acceleration due to gravity on the earth's surface at the poles is $g$ and angular velocity of the earth about the axis passing through the pole is $\omega$ An object is weighed at the equator and at a height $h$ above the poles by using a spring balance. If the weights are found to be same, then $h$ is: $(h< < R,$ where $R$ is the radius of the earth)

solution.text:
Value of $g$ at equator, $g_{A}=g \cdot-R \omega^{2}$ Value of $g$ at height $h$ above the pole, $g_{B}=g \cdot\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)$
As object is weighed equally at the equator and poles, it means $g$ is same at these places.
$g_{A}=g_{B}$
$\Rightarrow g-R \omega^{2}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)$
$\Rightarrow R \omega^{2}=\frac{2 g h}{R} \Rightarrow h=\frac{R^{2} \omega^{2}}{2 g}$

question.text: A satellite is in an elliptical orbit around a planet $\mathrm{P}$. It is observed that the velocity of the satellite when it is farthest from the planet is 6 times less than that when it is closest to the planet. The ratio of distances between the satellite and the planet at closest and farthest points is :

solution.text:
By angular momentum conservation $r_{\min } v_{\max }=m r_{\max } v_{\min }$
Given, $v_{\min }=\frac{v_{\max }}{6}$ $\therefore \frac{r_{\min }}{r_{\max }}=\frac{v_{\min }}{v_{\max }}=\frac{1}{6}$

question.text: Two planets have masses $M$ and $16 M$ and their radii are $a$ and $2 a$, respectively. The separation between the centres of the planets is $10 a$. A body of mass $m$ is fired from the surface of the larger planet towards the smaller planet along the line joining their centres. For the body to be able to reach the surface of smaller planet, the minimum firing speed needed is:

solution.text: Let $A$ be the point where gravitation field of both planets cancel each other i.e. zero. $\frac{G M}{x^{2}}=\frac{G(16 M)}{(10 a-x)^{2}}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x}=\frac{4}{(10 a-x)} \Rightarrow 4 x=10 a-x \Rightarrow x=2 a$ Using conservation of energy, we have $-\frac{G M m}{8 a}-\frac{G(16 M) m}{2 a}+K E=-\frac{G M m}{2 a}-\frac{G(16 M) m}{8 a}$ $K E=G M m\left[\frac{1}{8 a}+\frac{16}{2 a}-\frac{1}{2 a}-\frac{16}{8 a}\right]$ $\Rightarrow K E=G M m\left[\frac{1+64-4-16}{8 a}\right]$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=G M m\left[\frac{45}{8 a}\right] \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{90 G M}{8 a}}$ $\Rightarrow v=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{\frac{5 G M}{a}}$

question.text: Four identical particles of equal masses <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kg</mi></math> made to move along the circumference of a circle of radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> under the action of their own mutual gravitational attraction. The speed of each particle will be:

solution.text:
F1=Gmm2R2=Gm24R2

 F2=Gmm2R2=Gm22R2

⇒v=G1+222

question.text: Two stars of masses <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>m</mi></math> at a distance d rotate about their common centre of mass in free space. The period of revolution is

solution.text:
F=G2mmd2=2mω2d/3

Gmd2=ω2d3

⇒ω2=3Gmd3

⇒ω=3Gmd3

⇒T=2πω=2πd33Gm

question.text:
A body weighs 49 N on a spring balance at the north pole. What will be its weight recorded on the same weighing machine, if it is shifted to the equator?

[Use g=GMR2=9.8 ms-2 and radius of earth, R=6400 km.]

solution.text:
Weight of pole =mg=49 N

At equator due to rotation =ge=g-Rω2

so W=mge=mg-Rω2

∴  WP>We Wp=49 N

So, We=48.83 N. We<49 N

question.text: A solid sphere of radius R gravitationally attracts a particle placed at 3R from its centre with a force F1. Now a spherical cavity of radius R2 is made in the sphere (as shown in figure) and the force becomes F2. The value of F1:F2 is:

solution.text:
Let initial mass of sphere is m'. Hence mass of
removed portion will be m'/8

F1=m.E.=m.Gm'9R2

=Gm'9 R2-Gm'×48×25

=19-150Gm'R2

F2=4150×9·Gm'R2

F1F2=19×50×941=5041

question.text:

question.text:
A satellite is launched into a circular orbit of radius $\mathrm{R}$ around earth, while a second satellite is launched into a circular orbit of radius $1.02 \mathrm{R}$. The percentage difference in the time periods of the
two satellites is :

solution.text:
$\mathrm{T}^{2} \propto \mathrm{R}^{3}$
$\mathrm{~T}=\mathrm{kR}^{3 / 2}$
$\frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{T}}=\frac{3}{2} \frac{\mathrm{dR}}{\mathrm{R}}$
$=\frac{3}{2} \times 0.02=0.03$
$\%$ Change $=3 \%$

question.text: Consider a binary star system of star A and star B with masses $\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}}$ revolving in a circular orbit of radii $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{B}}$, respectively. If $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}$ are the time period of star $\mathrm{A}$ and $\operatorname{star} \mathrm{B}$, respectively, then :

solution.text: $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}\left(\right.$ since $\left.\omega_{\mathrm{A}}=\omega_{\mathrm{B}}\right)$

question.text:
A body is projected vertically upwards from the
surface of earth with a velocity sufficient enough
to carry it to infinity. The time taken by it to reach
height $\mathrm{h}$ is
$\mathrm{S}$.

solution.text: $\begin{aligned} & \text { Applying energy conservation from (1) to (2) } \\ & \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \cdot\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}_{e}}\right)-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}_{e}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{r}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{r}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & \mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{r}}}=\frac{\mathrm{dr}}{\mathrm{dt}} \\ \Rightarrow & \sqrt{2 \mathrm{GM}} \int_{0}^{\mathrm{t}} \mathrm{dt}=\int_{\mathrm{R}_{e}}^{\mathrm{R}_{e} \mathrm{th}}(\sqrt{\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{r}}) \mathrm{dr} \\ & \sqrt{2 \mathrm{GM}} \cdot \mathrm{t}=\frac{2}{3}\left[(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{r})^{3 / 2}\right]_{R_{e}}^{\mathrm{R}_{e}+\mathrm{h}} \\ & \mathrm{t}=\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{R}_{e}^{3}}{2 \mathrm{GM}}}\left[\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{e}}\right)^{3 / 2}-1\right] \\ & \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}_{e}^{2}}=\mathrm{g} \\ & \mathrm{t}=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{R}_{e}}{\mathrm{~g}}}\left[\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{e}}\right)^{3 / 2}-1\right] \end{aligned}$

question.text: The minimum and maximum distances of a planet revolving around the Sun are $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$. If the minimum speed of the planet on its trajectory is $\mathrm{v}_{0}$ then its maximum speed will be:

solution.text:
Angular momentum conservation equation $\mathrm{v}_{0} \mathrm{x}_{2}=\mathrm{v}_{1} \mathrm{x}_{1}$
$\mathrm{v}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{v}_{0} \mathrm{x}_{2}}{\mathrm{x}_{1}}$

question.text: Consider a planet in some solar system which has a mass double the mass of earth and density equal to the average density of earth. If the weight of an object on earth is $\mathrm{W}$, the weight of the same object on that planet will be :

solution.text:
Density is same $\mathrm{M}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{R}^{3} \rho, 2 \mathrm{~m}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{R}^{33} \rho$
$\mathrm{R}^{\prime}=2^{1 / 3} \mathrm{R}$
$\omega=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$
$\omega_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{G} 2 \mathrm{Mm}}{\mathrm{R}^{\prime 2}}$
$\omega_{2}=2^{1 / 3} \omega$

question.text: Two identical particles of mass $1 \mathrm{~kg}$ each go round a circle of radius $\mathrm{R}$, under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction. The angular speed of each particle is :

question.text:
Inside a uniform spherical shell :
(a) the gravitational field is zero
(b) the gravitational potential is zero
(c) the gravitational field is same everywhere
(d) the gravitation potential is same everywhere
(e) all of the above
Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below :

solution.text: Inside a spherical shell, gravitational field is zero and hence potential remains same everywhere Hence option (1)

question.text: A mass of $50 \mathrm{~kg}$ is placed at the centre of a uniform spherical shell of mass $100 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $50 \mathrm{~m}$. If the gravitational potential at a point, $25 \mathrm{~m}$ from the centre is $\mathrm{V} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}$. The value of $\mathrm{V}$ is :

solution.text: $\begin{aligned} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}} &=\left[-\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{1}}{\mathrm{r}}-\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{2}}{\mathrm{R}}\right] \\ &=\left[-\frac{50}{25} \mathrm{G}-\frac{100}{50} \mathrm{G}\right] \\ &=-4 \mathrm{G} \end{aligned}$

question.text: The masses and radii of the earth and moon are $\left(M_{1}, R_{1}\right)$ and $\left(M_{2}, R_{2}\right)$ respectively. Their centres are at a distance 'r' apart. Find the minimum escape velocity for a particle of mass 'm' to be projected from the middle of these two masses:

solution.text:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{2} m V^{2}-\frac{G M_{1} m}{r / 2}-\frac{G M_{2} m}{r / 2}=0 \\
\frac{1}{2} m V^{2}=\frac{2 G m}{r}\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right) \\
V=\sqrt{\frac{4 G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}{r}}
\end{array}
$$
Option (2)

question.text:
If $R_{E}$ be the radius of Earth, then the ratio between the acceleration due to gravity at a depth 'r' below and a height 'r' above the earth surface is :
(Given : $\mathrm{r} < \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{E}}$ )

solution.text:
$g_{\text {up }}=\frac{g}{\left(1+\frac{r}{R}\right)^{2}}$
$g_{\text {down }}=g\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)$
$\frac{g_{\text {down }}}{g_{\text {up }}}=\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)\left(1+\frac{r}{R}\right)^{2}$
$\quad=\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)\left(1+\frac{2 r}{R}+\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right)$
$\quad=1+\frac{r}{R}-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}}$

question.text: Four particles each of mass $\mathrm{M}$, move along a circle of radius $\mathrm{R}$ under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction as shown in figure. The speed of each particle is :

solution.text:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
F_{\text {net }}=\frac{M V^{2}}{R} \\
\sqrt{2} F+F_{1}=\frac{M V^{2}}{R} \\
\sqrt{2} \frac{G M M}{(\sqrt{2} R)^{2}}+\frac{G M M}{(2 R)^{2}}=\frac{M V^{2}}{R} \\
\frac{G M}{R}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{1}{4}\right)=V^{2} \\
\frac{G M}{R}\left(\frac{4+\sqrt{2}}{4 \sqrt{2}}\right)=V^{2} \\
V=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{G M(2 \sqrt{2}+1)}{R}}
\end{array}
$$
Option (2)
